data.title: County has 17 named to 2019 All-State football team - Shelby County Reporter
data.meta_description: Featuring the best offensive and defensive players from each classification and separated into two teams, the 2019 All-State team featured 17 names from Shelby County following a historic football season.
data.text:
County has 17 named to 2019 All-State football team

Published 9:17 am Sunday, December 22, 2019

By ALEC ETHEREDGE | Sports Editor

Featuring the best offensive and defensive players from each classification and separated into two teams, the 2019 All-State team featured 17 names from Shelby County following a historic football season.

While it’s two less than the number we saw on the 2018 team, it’s a talented group of players featuring eight first-team players, seven second-team players, one honorable mention players and one Coach of the Year.

That coach of the year came in the 7A classification, as Thompson head coach Mark Freeman earned the award after leading the Warriors to their first championship in 37 years and second in school history, despite losing several starters from his 2018 team.

As for the players, several of the ones Freeman coached were on the All-State team as well, including three first-team players.

Quarterback Sawyer Pate, receiver Mike Pettway and linebacker Jeremiah Alexander all made the Class 7A All-State team after playing major roles in leading the team to a title.

Pate finished the season with 3,125 passing yards and the third highest completion percentage for a single season in state history at 74.6. He also threw for 41 touchdowns, which is the 12th best mark for a single season in state history.

His favorite target this year was Pettway, who totaled 1,154 receiving yards and 16 touchdowns on 53 receptions.

Still just a sophomore at Thompson, Alexander was a leader on the defense, posting 118 total tackles, 25 tackles for loss and 8.5 sacks this season.

Beyond those three, Helena’s Seaburn Hines, Briarwood’s Trent Howard and Cole Garner, Montevallo’s Jamarius Carter and Vincent’s Tae McGregor were all named to the first team of their respective classification as well.

Hines continues to be one of the county’s best offensive linemen, and will return for one final year with the Huskies next year. Head coach Richie Busby says he’s the best he’s ever coached.

Similar words can be said about Howard at Briarwood, who is now heading to Clemson after a remarkable career with the Lions that saw former head coach Fred Yancey and current head coach Matthew Forester call him the best they’ve ever seen.

Garner was also a monster for the Lions this year, posting 69 total tackles, including 12 tackles for loss and seven sacks with three recovered fumbles.

At Montevallo, Carter was the team’s leading receiver this year thanks to his height and athleticism. The senior had a breakout season after picking football back up last year, and totaled 1,031 yards with 15 touchdowns on 49 receptions.

Beyond those first-team players, Thompson’s Evan McGurie, Spain Park’s Harrison Barker and Oak Mountain’s Drew Padgett and Sam Johnson earned spots on the Class 7A Second Team.

Barker, who was also a second team All-County player, posted 2,946 passing yards this season and was 232-for-369 with 21 touchdown passes.

McGuire was an impressive kicker this year, especially on kickoffs with close to 90 percent of his kickoffs ending in touchbacks. He was also a strong punter with 15 punts inside the 20-yard line. He made eight of his nine field goals attempts this season and had a long of 44 yards, while going 65 of 72 on extra points.

For the Eagles, Padgett was a leader on the offensive line and is now headed to Jacksonville State University, while Johnson was arguably the best punter in the state this season. With a booming leg, he also pinned 11 punts inside the 20-yard line this season.

Beyond that, Helena’s Marquis Johnson and Nathan Dunaway and Briarwood’s Tyler Waugh were all named to the second team of Class 6A and Class 5A, respectively, while Calera’s Jayson Jones earned an honorable mention spot in Class 6A.

Johnson was the county’s leading rusher this season with 1,478 yards and 26 touchdowns on 207 carries as a junior. He led the Huskies’ offense, while Dunaway led the defense with 129 tackles, including 12 tackles for loss and three sacks.

Jones, who is currently committed to the University of Alabama, faced double and triple teams all season and still posted 15 tackles for loss this season and seven sacks. Regardless of where he landed on this list, he’s one of the best linemen in the state.

FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

Offense
